A strangle is an options strategy in which the investor holds a position in both a call and a put option with different strike prices, but with the same expiration date and underlying asset.
A strategic alliance is an arrangement between two companies to undertake a mutually beneficial project while each retains its independence.

Strategic financial management means not only managing a company's finances but managing them with the intention to succeed—that is, to attain the company's long-term goals and objectives and maximize shareholder value over time.
Strategic management is the management of an organization’s resources to achieve its goals and objectives.
Stratified random sampling is a method of sampling that involves the division of a population into smaller sub-groups known as strata.

ent_name: Strength, Weakness, Opportunity, and Threat (SWOT) Analysis
sent: SWOT (strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats) analysis is a framework used to evaluate a company's competitive position and to develop strategic planning.
Stress testing is a computer simulation technique used to test the resilience of institutions and investment portfolios against possible future financial situations.
A strike price is a set price at which a derivative contract can be bought or sold when it is exercised.

Structural unemployment is a longer-lasting form of unemployment caused by fundamental shifts in an economy and exacerbated by extraneous factors such as technology, competition, and government policy.

Structured finance is a heavily involved financial instrument presented to large financial institutions or companies with complicated financing needs who are unsatisfied with conventional financial products.
A structured note is a debt obligation that also contains an embedded derivative component that adjusts the security's risk-return profile.
Student loan forgiveness releases borrowers from their obligation to repay part or all of their federal student loan debt.
Subjective probability is a type of probability derived from an individual's personal judgment or own experience about whether a specific outcome is likely to occur.
A sublease is the re-renting of property by an existing tenant to a new third party for a portion of the tenant’s existing lease contract.
Subordinated debt (also known as a subordinated debenture) is an unsecured loan or bond that ranks below other, more senior loans or securities with respect to claims on assets or earnings.
A subordination agreement is a legal document that establishes one debt as ranking behind another in priority for collecting repayment from a debtor.
A subprime loan is a type of loan offered at a rate above prime to individuals who do not qualify for prime-rate loans.
A subprime mortgage is one that’s normally issued to borrowers with low credit ratings.
Subrogation is a term describing a right held by most insurance carriers to legally pursue a third party that caused an insurance loss to the insured.
A subscription agreement is an investor's application to join a limited partnership (LP).
In the corporate world, a subsidiary is a company that belongs to another company, which is usually referred to as the parent company or the holding company.
A subsidy is a benefit given to an individual, business, or institution, usually by the government.

Substantially Equal Periodic Payment, or SEPP, is a method of distributing funds from an IRA or other qualified retirement plans prior to the age of 59½ that avoids incurring IRS penalties for the withdrawals.
A substitute, or substitutable good, in economics and consumer theory refers to a product or service that consumers see as essentially the same or similar-enough to another product.
The substitution effect is the decrease in sales for a product that can be attributed to consumers switching to cheaper alternatives when its price rises.
A sukuk is an Islamic financial certificate, similar to a bond in Western finance, that complies with Islamic religious law commonly known as Sharia.
Sum of squares is a statistical technique used in regression analysis to determine the dispersion of data points.
The sum-of-the-parts valuation (SOTP) is a process of valuing a company by determining what its aggregate divisions would be worth if they were spun off or acquired by another company.
Summa cum laude is an honorary title used by educational institutions to signify a degree that was earned "with the highest distinction.
A sunk cost refers to money that has already been spent and cannot be recovered.
A superannuation is an organizational pension program created by a company for the benefit of its employees.
A supplemental executive retirement plan (SERP) is a set of benefits that may be made available to top-level employees in addition to those covered in the company's standard retirement savings plan.
Supply is a fundamental economic concept that describes the total amount of a specific good or service that is available to consumers.
A supply chain is a network of individuals and companies who are involved in creating a product and delivering it to the consumer.

Supply chain finance (SCF) is a term describing a set of technology-based solutions that aim to lower financing costs and improve business efficiency for buyers and sellers linked in a sales transaction.
Supply chain management is the management of the flow of goods and services and includes all processes that transform raw materials into final products.
The supply curve is a graphic representation of the correlation between the cost of a good or service and the quantity supplied for a given period.
A supply shock is an unexpected event that suddenly changes the supply of a product or commodity, resulting in an unforeseen change in price.
Support, or a support level, refers to the price level that an asset does not fall below for period of time.

A supranational organization is a multinational union or association in which member countries cede authority and sovereignty on at least some internal matters to the group, whose decisions are binding on its members.
A surcharge is an extra fee, charge, or tax that is added on to the cost of a good or service, beyond the initially quoted price.
The surety is the guarantee of the debts of one party by another.
A surplus describes the amount of an asset or resource that exceeds the portion that's actively utilized.
Surplus lines insurance protects against a financial risk that is too high for a regular insurance company to take on.

Survivorship bias or survivor bias is the tendency to view the performance of existing stocks or funds in the market as a representative comprehensive sample without regarding those that have gone bust.
In the broadest sense, sustainability refers to the ability to maintain or support a process continuously over time.
The sustainable growth rate (SGR) is the maximum rate of growth that a company or social enterprise can sustain without having to finance growth with additional equity or debt.
A swap is a derivative contract through which two parties exchange the cash flows or liabilities from two different financial instruments.
A Swap Execution Facility (SEF) is an electronic platform provided by a corporate entity that allows participants to buy and sell swaps in a regulated and transparent manner.
A swap rate is the rate of the fixed leg of a swap as determined by its particular market and the parties involved.
A swaption, also known as a swap option, refers to an option to enter into an interest rate swap or some other type of swap.
The term sweat equity refers to a person or company's contribution toward a business venture or other project.

A sweep account is a bank or brokerage account that automatically transfers amounts that exceed, or fall short of, a certain level into a higher interest-earning investment option at the close of each business day.
Swing trading is a style of trading that attempts to capture short- to medium-term gains in a stock (or any financial instrument) over a period of a few days to several weeks.
A swingline loan is a short-term loan made by financial institutions that provides businesses with access to funds to cover debt commitments.
Switching costs are the costs that a consumer incurs as a result of changing brands, suppliers, or products.
A symmetrical distribution occurs when the values of variables appear at regular frequencies and often the mean, median, and mode all occur at the same point.
A syndicate is a temporary alliance of businesses that joins together to manage a large transaction, which would be difficult, or impossible, to effect individually.
A syndicated loan, also known as a syndicated bank facility, is financing offered by a group of lenders—referred to as a syndicate—who work together to provide funds for a single borrower.
Synergy is the concept that the combined value and performance of two companies will be greater than the sum of the separate individual parts.
Synthetic is the term given to financial instruments that are engineered to simulate other instruments while altering key characteristics, like duration and cash flow.
A systematic investment plan (SIP) is a plan in which investors make regular, equal payments into a mutual fund, trading account, or retirement account such as a 401(k).
Systemic risk is the possibility that an event at the company level could trigger severe instability or collapse an entire industry or economy.
Systematic sampling is a type of probability sampling method in which sample members from a larger population are selected according to a random starting point but with a fixed, periodic interval.
T+1 (T+2, T+3) are abbreviations that refer to the settlement date of security transactions.
The T distribution, also known as the Student’s t-distribution, is a type of probability distribution that is similar to the normal distribution with its bell shape but has heavier tails.
A T-account is an informal term for a set of financial records that uses double-entry bookkeeping.
A t-test is an inferential statistic used to determine if there is a significant difference between the means of two groups and how they are related.

Tactical asset allocation is an active management portfolio strategy that shifts the percentage of assets held in various categories to take advantage of market pricing anomalies or strong market sectors.
The Taft-Hartley Act is a 1947 U.
Tag-along rights also referred to as "co-sale rights," are contractual obligations used to protect a minority shareholder, usually in a venture capital deal.

The Taguchi method of quality control is an approach to engineering that emphasizes the roles of research and development (R&D), and product design and development in reducing the occurrence of defects and failures in manufactured goods.

Tail risk is a form of portfolio risk that arises when the possibility that an investment will move more than three standard deviations from the mean is greater than what is shown by a normal distribution.
Takaful is a type of Islamic insurance wherein members contribute money into a pool system to guarantee each other against loss or damage.
Takaful is a type of Islamic insurance wherein members contribute money into a pool system to guarantee each other against loss or damage.
Take or pay is a provision, written into a contract, whereby one party has the obligation of either taking delivery of goods or paying a specified amount.
A take-out loan is a type of long-term financing that replaces short-term interim financing.
A take-profit order (T/P) is a type of limit order that specifies the exact price at which to close out an open position for a profit.
A takeover occurs when one company makes a successful bid to assume control of or acquire another.
A tangible asset is an asset that has a finite monetary value and usually a physical form.
Tangible book value per share (TBVPS) is a method by which a company’s value is determined on a per-share basis by measuring its equity without the inclusion of any intangible assets.
Tangible common equity (TCE) is a measure of a company's physical capital, which is used to evaluate a financial institution's ability to deal with potential losses.
Tangible net worth is most commonly a calculation of the net worth of a company that excludes any value derived from intangible assets such as copyrights, patents, and intellectual property.
Tangible personal property is a tax term describing personal property that can be physically relocated, such as furniture and office equipment.
Tape reading is an old technique that day traders used to analyze the price and volume of a given stock.
The phrase, taper tantrum, describes the 2013 surge in U.
Tapering modifies a central bank's monetary expansion policies initiated to stimulate an economy.
Target-date funds are mutual funds or exchange-traded funds (ETFs) structured to grow assets in a way that is optimized for a specific time frame.
A target market is a group of people with some shared characteristics that a company has identified as potential customers for its products.
A targeted accrual redemption note (TARN) is an exotic derivative that terminates when a limit on coupon payments to the holder is reached.
A tariff is a tax imposed by one country on the goods and services imported from another country.
Tax accounting is a structure of accounting methods focused on taxes rather than the appearance of public financial statements.
The term “tax-advantaged” refers to any type of investment, financial account, or savings plan that is either exempt from taxation, tax-deferred, or that offers other types of tax benefits.
The term tax avoidance refers to the use of legal methods to minimize the amount of income tax owed by an individual or a business.
A tax base is a total amount of assets or income that can be taxed by a taxing authority, usually by the government.
The term tax benefit refers to any tax law that helps you reduce your tax liability.
A tax bracket refers to a range of incomes subject to a certain income tax rate.
The term tax break refers to a benefit the government offers that reduces your total tax liability.
A tax credit is an amount of money that taxpayers can subtract directly from the taxes they owe.
Tax-deductible interest is a borrowing expense that a taxpayer can claim on a federal or state tax return to reduce taxable income.
A tax deduction is an item you can subtract from your taxable income to lower the amount of taxes you owe.
The term “tax deed” refers to a legal document granting ownership of a property to a government body when the owner fails to pay any associated property taxes.
Tax-deferred status refers to investment earnings—such as interest, dividends, or capital gains—that accumulate tax-free until the investor takes constructive receipt of the profits.

ent_name: Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 1982 (TEFRA)
sent: The Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 1982 (TEFRA) is a law passed in 1982 that was designed to reduce the federal budget deficit through a combination of tax increases, spending cuts, and tax reform measures.
The tax-equivalent yield is the return that a taxable bond would need to equal the yield on a comparable tax-exempt municipal bond.
Tax evasion is an illegal activity in which a person or entity deliberately avoids paying a true tax liability.
Tax-exempt refers to income or transactions that are free from tax at the federal, state, or local level.
Tax-exempt interest is interest income that is not subject to federal income tax.
A tax expense is a liability owed to federal, state/provincial, and/or municipal governments within a given period, typically over the course of a year.
Tax fraud occurs when an individual or business entity willfully and intentionally falsifies information on a tax return to limit the amount of tax liability.
Tax free refers to certain types of goods and financial securities (such as municipal bonds) that are not taxed.
A tax-free savings account (TFSA) is a Canadian account in which contributions, interest earned, dividends, and capital gains aren't taxed can be withdrawn tax-free.
A tax haven is a country that offers foreign businesses and individuals minimal or no tax liability for their bank deposits in a politically and economically stable environment.
A tax holiday is a temporary tax break.
A Tax Identification Number (TIN) is a nine-digit number used as a tracking number by the Internal Revenue Service (IRS).
"Tax incidence" (or incidence of tax) is an economic term for understanding the division of a tax burden between stakeholders, such as buyers and sellers or producers and consumers.
Tax liability is the payment owed by an individual, a business, or other entity to a federal, state, or local tax authority.
A tax lien is a legal claim against the assets of an individual or business that fails to pay taxes owed to the government.
A tax lien certificate is a certificate of claim against a property that has a lien placed upon it as a result of unpaid property taxes.
A tax loss carryforward (or carryover) is a provision that allows a taxpayer to move a tax loss to future years to offset a profit.
Tax-loss harvesting is the timely selling of securities at a loss in order to offset the amount of capital gains tax due on the sale of other securities at a profit.
Tax planning is the analysis of a financial situation or plan to ensure that all elements work together to allow you to pay the lowest taxes possible.
A tax rate is the percentage at which an individual or corporation is taxed.
The Tax Reform Act of 1986 is a law passed by the United States Congress to simplify the income tax code.
A tax refund is a reimbursement to a taxpayer for any excess amount paid to the federal government or a state government.
Tax relief refers to any government program or policy designed to help individuals and businesses reduce their tax burdens or resolve their tax-related debts.
A tax return is a form or forms filed with a tax authority that reports income, expenses, and other pertinent tax information.
Tax season is the time period, generally between Jan.
Tax selling refers to a type of sale in which an investor sells an asset with a capital loss in order to lower or eliminate the capital gain realized by other investments, for income tax purposes.
A tax shelter is a vehicle used by individuals or organizations to minimize or decrease their taxable incomes and, therefore, tax liabilities.
A tax-sheltered annuity is a type of investment vehicle that lets an employee make pretax contributions into a retirement account from income.

A tax shield is a reduction in taxable income for an individual or corporation achieved through claiming allowable deductions such as mortgage interest, medical expenses, charitable donations, amortization, and depreciation.
The term tax table refers to a chart that displays the amount of tax due based on income received.
A tax-to-GDP ratio is a gauge of a nation's tax revenue relative to the size of its economy as measured by gross domestic product (GDP).
A tax treaty is a bilateral (two-party) agreement made by two countries to resolve issues involving double taxation of passive and active income of each of their respective citizens.
A tax wedge is the difference between before-tax and after-tax wages.
Taxable income is the portion of your gross income used to calculate how much tax you owe in a given tax year.
The taxable wage base is the maximum amount of earned income that employees must pay Social Security taxes on.
Taxation is a term for when a taxing authority, usually a government, levies or imposes a financial obligation on its citizens or residents.
The phrase taxation without representation describes a populace that is required to pay taxes to a government authority without having any say in that government's policies.
Taxes are mandatory contributions levied on individuals or corporations by a government entity—whether local, regional, or national.
A taxpayer may be an individual or business entity that is obligated to pay taxes to a federal, state, or local government.
The Taylor Rule (sometimes referred to as Taylor's rule or Taylor principle) is an equation linking the Federal Reserve's benchmark interest rate to levels of inflation and economic growth.

The Teacher Retirement System (TRS) is a network of state and city-level organizations that collectively administer pensions and retirement accounts for public education employees within their states.

The Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association (TIAA) is a financial organization that provides investment and insurance services for those working for organizations in the nonprofit industry in academic, research, medical, government, and cultural fields.

Technical analysis is a trading discipline employed to evaluate investments and identify trading opportunities by analyzing statistical trends gathered from trading activity, such as price movement and volume.
Technical analysis is the study of historical market data, including price and volume.
A technical analyst, also known as a chartist or market technician, is a securities researcher or trader who analyzes investments based on past market prices and technical indicators.
Technical indicators are heuristic or pattern-based signals produced by the price, volume, and/or open interest of a security or contract used by traders who follow technical analysis.
Technical job skills, sometimes referred to as hard skills, are specific talents and expertise an individual possesses that help them perform a certain task or job.

Technical skills refer to the specialized knowledge and expertise needed to accomplish complex actions, tasks, and processes relating to computational and physical technology as well as a diverse group of other enterprises.
A technocracy is a model of governance wherein decision-makers are chosen for office based on their technical expertise and background.
The technology, media, and telecom (TMT) sector is an industry grouping that includes the majority of companies focused on new technologies.
The technology sector is the category of stocks relating to the research, development, or distribution of technologically based goods and services.
The TED spread is the difference between the three-month Treasury bill and the three-month LIBOR based in U.
A telegraphic transfer (TT) is an electronic method of transferring funds utilized primarily for overseas wire transactions.
The temporal method (also known as the historical method) converts the currency of a foreign subsidiary into the currency of the parent company.

Tenancy at sufferance is an agreement in which a property renter is legally permitted to live on a property after a lease term has expired but before the landlord demands the tenant vacate the property.
A tenancy-at-will is a property tenure that can be terminated at any time by either the tenant or the owner/landlord.
Tenancy by the entirety refers to a form of shared property ownership that is reserved only for married couples.
Tenancy in Common (TIC) is a legal arrangement in which two or more parties share ownership rights in a real estate property or parcel of land.
Tenants by entirety (TBE) is a method in some states by which married couples can hold the title to a property.
A tender is an invitation to bid for a project or accept a formal offer such as a takeover bid.
A tender offer is a bid to purchase some or all of shareholders' stock in a corporation.
Tenkan-Sen, or Conversion Line, is the mid-point of the highest and lowest prices of an asset over the last nine periods.
Tenor refers to the length of time remaining before a financial contract expires.
A term deposit is a fixed-term investment that includes the deposit of money into an account at a financial institution.
A term deposit is a fixed-term investment that includes the deposit of money into an account at a financial institution.
A term loan provides borrowers with a lump sum of cash upfront in exchange for specific borrowing terms.
A term sheet is a nonbinding agreement that shows the basic terms and conditions of an investment.
The term structure of interest rates, commonly known as the yield curve, depicts the interest rates of similar quality bonds at different maturities.
A bond's term to maturity is the length of time during which the owner will receive interest payments on the investment.
The terminal capitalization rate, also known as the exit rate, is the rate used to estimate the resale value of a property at the end of the holding period.
Terminal value (TV) is the value of an asset, business, or project beyond the forecasted period when future cash flows can be estimated.
The term termination of employment refers to the end of an employee’s work with a company.
Terms of employment refer to the responsibilities and benefits associated with a job as agreed upon by an employer and employee at the time of hiring.
Terms of trade (TOT) represent the ratio between a country's export prices and its import prices.
The tertiary industry is a technical name for the services sector of the economy, which encompasses a wide range of businesses, including financial institutions, schools, hotels, and restaurants.
A testamentary trust is a trust that is established in accordance with the instructions contained in a last will and testament.
Tether (USDT) is a cryptocurrency stablecoin pegged to the U.
The Texas ratio was developed to warn of credit problems at particular banks or banks in particular regions.
Tezos is a blockchain network hosting the associated digital token Tez (XTZ), which is also known as tezzie.
The Greatest Generation is a term used to describe those Americans who grew up during the Great Depression and fought in World War II, or whose labor helped win it.
A theoretical ex-rights price (TERP) is the market price that a stock will theoretically have following a new rights issue.
The theoretical value (of a right) is the value of a subscription right.
The theory of price is an economic theory that states that the price for a specific good or service is determined by the relationship between its supply and demand at any given point.

In neoclassical economics—an approach to economics focusing on the determination of goods, outputs, and income distributions in markets through supply and demand—the theory of the firm is a microeconomic concept that states that a firm exists and make decisions to maximize profits.

ent_name: There Ain't No Such Thing as a Free Lunch (TANSTAAFL)
sent: "There ain't no such thing as a free lunch" (TANSTAAFL), also known as "there is no such thing as a free lunch" (TINSTAAFL), is an expression that describes the cost of decision-making and consumption.
The term theta refers to the rate of decline in the value of an option due to the passage of time.
A third party is an individual or entity that is involved in a transaction but is not one of the principals and, thus, has a lesser interest in the transaction.
Third-party insurance is a policy purchased by the insured (first party) from the insurance company (second party) for protection against the claims of another (third party).
A third-party transaction is a business deal that involves a person or entity other than the main participants.
"Third World" is an outdated and derogatory phrase that has been used historically to describe a class of economically developing nations.
Thomas Robert Malthus was a famous 18th-century British economist known for the population growth philosophies outlined in his 1798 book "An Essay on the Principle of Population.
Three black crows is a phrase used to describe a bearish candlestick pattern that may predict the reversal of an uptrend.
Three-sigma limits is a statistical calculation where the data are within three standard deviations from a mean.
Three white soldiers is a bullish candlestick pattern that is used to predict the reversal of the current downtrend in a pricing chart.
Even though they're not as common as they used to be, thrifts, or savings and loan associations, still play an important part in many consumers' lives.
A thrift bank–also just called a thrift–is a type of financial institution that specializes in offering savings accounts and originating home mortgages for consumers.
A thrift savings plan (TSP) is a type of retirement investment program open only to federal employees and members of the uniformed services, including the Ready Reserve.
Throughput, in business, is the amount of a product or service that a company can produce and deliver to a client within a specified period of time.
A tick is a measure of the minimum upward or downward movement in the price of a security.
Tick size refers to the minimum price movement of a trading instrument in a market.
Tier 1 capital refers to the core capital held in a bank's reserves and is used to fund business activities for the bank's clients.
The tier 1 capital ratio is the ratio of a bank’s core tier 1 capital—that is, its equity capital and disclosed reserves—to its total risk-weighted assets.
Tier 1 common capital ratio is a measurement of a bank's core equity capital, compared with its total risk-weighted assets, and signifies a bank's financial strength.
The Tier 1 leverage ratio measures a bank's core capital relative to its total assets.
The term tier 2 capital refers to one of the components of a bank's required reserves.

Tight, or contractionary monetary policy is a course of action undertaken by a central bank such as the Federal Reserve to slow down overheated economic growth, to constrict spending in an economy that is seen to be accelerating too quickly, or to curb inflation when it is rising too fast.
A Timber Investment Management Organization (TIMO) is a management group that aids institutional investors in managing their timberland investment portfolios.
Time decay is a measure of the rate of decline in the value of an options contract due to the passage of time.
A time deposit is an interest-bearing bank account that has a pre-set date of maturity.

ent_name: What Is an Investment Time Horizon?
sent: An investment time horizon, or just time horizon, is the period of time one expects to hold an investment until they need the money back.
Time in force is a special instruction used when placing a trade to indicate how long an order will remain active before it is executed or expires.
The times interest earned (TIE) ratio is a measure of a company's ability to meet its debt obligations based on its current income.
A time series is a sequence of data points that occur in successive order over some period of time.
Time value refers to the portion of an option's premium that is attributable to the amount of time remaining until the expiration of the option contract.
The time value of money (TVM) is the concept that a sum of money is worth more now than the same sum will be at a future date due to its earnings potential in the interim.
The time-weighted rate of return (TWR) is a measure of the compound rate of growth in a portfolio.
The times-revenue method is a valuation method used to determine the maximum value of a company.

"There is no alternative," often abbreviated as "TINA," is a phrase that originated with the Victorian philosopher Herbert Spencer and later became a slogan for British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher in the 1980s.
Tit for tat is a game-theory strategy subject to a payoff matrix like that of a prisoner's dilemma.
Title insurance is a form of indemnity insurance that protects lenders and homebuyers from financial loss sustained from defects in a title to a property.
The term title search refers to the examination of public records to determine and confirm a property's legal ownership.
To be announced, or TBA in bond trading, is a term that describes forward-settling of mortgage-backed securities (MBS) trades.

A tobacco or cigarette tax is a tax imposed on all tobacco products by various levels of government, often with the alleged goal of reducing tobacco use or at least generating revenues earmarked to fund related healthcare programs.
The Tobin tax is a tax levied on spot currency conversions, with the intention of disincentivizing short-term currency speculation, named after economist James Tobin.
The Tokyo Price Index—commonly referred to as TOPIX—is a metric for stock prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange (TSE).
A tombstone is a written advertisement of a public offering placed by investment bankers who are underwriting the issue.

Tomorrow next (tom next) is a short-term foreign exchange (forex) transaction where a currency is simultaneously bought and sold over two separate business days: those being tomorrow (in one business day) and the following day (two business days from today).

Tontine is the name of an early system for raising capital in which individuals pay into a common pool of money; they receive dividends based on their share of returns from investments made with the pooled money.
“Too big to fail” describes a business or business sector deemed to be so deeply ingrained in a financial system or economy that its failure would be disastrous to the economy.
The top line is a reference to gross figures reported by a company, such as sales or revenue.
Top-down investing is an investment analysis approach that focuses on the macro factors of the economy, such as GDP, employment, taxation, interest rates, etc.
The term Toronto Stock Exchange (TSX) refers to a Canadian stock exchange located in Toronto, Ontario.
Tort law is the area of the law that covers most civil suits.
A total bond fund is a mutual fund or exchange-traded fund that seeks to replicate a broad bond index.
The total cost of ownership (TCO) is the purchase price of an asset plus the costs of operation.

The total debt service (TDS) ratio—total debt obligation divided by gross income—is a financial metric that lenders use to determine whether or not to extend credit, primarily in the mortgage industry.
The total debt-to-capitalization ratio is a tool that measures the total amount of outstanding company debt as a percentage of the firm’s total capitalization.
Total-debt-to-total-assets is a leverage ratio that defines the total amount of debt relative to assets owned by a company.
Total enterprise value (TEV) is a valuation measurement used to compare companies with varying levels of debt.
The total expense ratio (TER) is a measure of the total costs associated with managing and operating an investment fund, such as a mutual fund.
Total liabilities are the combined debts and obligations that an individual or company owes to outside parties.

Total quality management (TQM) is the continual process of detecting and reducing or eliminating errors in manufacturing, streamlining supply chain management, improving the customer experience, and ensuring that employees are up to speed with training.
Total return, when measuring performance, is the actual rate of return of an investment or a pool of investments over a given evaluation period.
A total return index is a type of equity index that tracks both the capital gains as well as any cash distributions, such as dividends or interest, attributed to the components of the index.

A total return swap is a swap agreement in which one party makes payments based on a set rate, either fixed or variable, while the other party makes payments based on the return of an underlying asset, which includes both the income it generates and any capital gains.
Total shareholder return (TSR) is a measure of financial performance, indicating the total amount an investor reaps from an investment—specifically, equities or shares of stock.
Total utility is the aggregate amount of satisfaction or fulfillment that a consumer receives through the consumption of a specific good or service.
A tracker fund is an index fund that tracks a broad market index or a segment thereof.
Tracking error is the divergence between the price behavior of a position or a portfolio and the price behavior of a benchmark.
A tracking stock is a special equity offering issued by a parent company that tracks the financial performance of a particular segment or division.
Trade refers to the voluntary exchange of goods or services between different economic actors.
Trade credit is a business-to-business (B2B) agreement in which a customer can purchase goods without paying cash up front, and paying the supplier at a later scheduled date.
A trade deficit occurs when a country's imports exceed its exports during a given time period.
Trade finance represents the financial instruments and products that are used by companies to facilitate international trade and commerce.
Trade liberalization is the removal or reduction of restrictions or barriers on the free exchange of goods between nations.
A trade line is a record of activity for any type of credit extended to a borrower and reported to a credit reporting agency.
Trade sanctions are legal restrictions on trade with a country.
A trade secret is any practice or process of a company that is generally not known outside of the company.
A trade signal is a trigger for action, either to buy or sell a security or other asset, generated by analysis.
A trade signal is a trigger for action, either to buy or sell a security or other asset, generated by analysis.
A trade war happens when one country retaliates against another by raising import tariffs or placing other restrictions on the other country's imports.
The term trademark refers to a recognizable insignia, phrase, word, or symbol that denotes a specific product and legally differentiates it from all other products of its kind.
A trader is an individual who engages in the buying and selling of financial assets in any financial market, either for themself or on behalf of another person or institution.
A trading account can be any investment account containing securities, cash or other holdings.
A trading book is the portfolio of financial instruments held by a brokerage or bank.
A trading desk is a physical location where transactions for buying and selling securities occur.
A trading halt is a temporary suspension of trading for a particular security or securities at one exchange or across numerous exchanges.
A trading house is a business that specializes in facilitating transactions between a home country and foreign countries.
A trading platform is a software system used to trade securities.

Unlevered free cash flow (UFCF) is a company's cash flow before taking interest payments into account.
Unlimited liability refers to the full legal responsibility that business owners and partners assume for all business debts.
An unlimited liability corporation (ULC) is a corporate structure used in Canada that allows shareholders to be liable if the company declares bankruptcy.
The unlimited marital deduction is a provision in the U.
Unlimited risk refers to a situation where there is potential for unlimited losses on a trade or in a particular investment.
An unlisted security is a financial instrument that is not traded on a formal exchange because it does not meet listing requirements.
Unlimited tax bonds are municipal bonds guaranteed by the full faith and credit of a government that can levy taxes until the debt is repaid.
Unlisted trading privileges (UTP) refer to the processes around the trading of a security that is not required to meet certain minimum requirements to be traded on an exchange.
Maturity mismatch is a term used to describe situations when there's a disconnect between a company's short-term assets and its short-term liabilities—specifically more of the latter than the former.
An unofficial strike is a work stoppage by union members that is not endorsed by the union and that does not follow the legal requirements for striking.
An unpaid dividend is a dividend that is due to be paid to shareholders but has not yet been distributed.
An unqualified audit reflects business financial statements that are transparent and compliant with generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP).

An unqualified opinion is an independent auditor's judgment that a company's financial statements are fairly and appropriately presented, without any identified exceptions, and in compliance with generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP).
An unquoted public company, also known as an unlisted public company, is a firm that has issued equity shares that are no longer traded on a stock exchange.
An unrealized gain is an increase in the value of an asset, such as a stock position or a commodity like gold, that has yet to be sold for cash.
An unrealized loss is a "paper" loss that results from holding an asset that has decreased in price, but not yet selling it and realizing the loss.

Unrecaptured section 1250 gain is an Internal Revenue Service (IRS) tax provision where previously recognized depreciation is recaptured into income when a gain is realized on the sale of depreciable real estate property.
An unrecorded deed refers to the situation where the title to a property, usually real estate, is not registered with the appropriate public records department.
Unregistered shares, also known as restricted stock, are securities that are not registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC).
Unrelated business taxable income (UBTI) is income regularly generated by a tax-exempt entity by means of taxable activities.
Unrestricted cash refers to cash that is readily available to be spent for any purpose and has not been pledged as collateral for a debt obligation or other purpose.
Unrestricted net assets are donations to nonprofit organizations that have no strings attached.

An unsatisfied judgment fund is the amount of money set aside by certain states to cover uncompensated expenses related to bodily injuries sustained in motor vehicle accidents where the responsible driver is unable to pay for the damages.
The importance of having adequate property insurance coverage can’t be overstated.
Unsecured refers to a debt or obligation that is not backed by any sort of collateral.
An unsecured creditor is an individual or institution that lends money without obtaining specified assets as collateral.
Unsecured debt refers to loans that are not backed by collateral.
An unsecured loan is a loan that doesn't require any type of collateral.
An unsecured note is a loan that is not secured by the issuer's assets.
"Unskilled labor" is an outdated term, once used to describe a segment of the workforce associated with a limited skill set or minimal economic value for the work performed.
An unsolicited application is a request for life insurance coverage that is made by an individual rather than an insurance agent or broker.
An unsolicited bid is an offer made by an individual, investors, or a company to purchase a company that is not actively seeking a buyer.
An unsponsored ADR is an American depositary receipt (ADR) issued by a depositary bank without the involvement, participation, or consent of the foreign company it represents ownership in.
Unstated interest paid is the amount of money the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) assumes has been paid to the seller of an item that has been sold on an installment basis.

The term unsterilized foreign exchange intervention refers to how a country's monetary authorities influence exchange rates and its money supply—by not purchasing foreign or by not selling domestic currencies or assets.
Unsubordinated debt, also known as a senior security or senior debt, refers to a type of obligation that must be repaid before any other form of debt.
The term unsubscribed refers to any shares that are part of an initial public offering (IPO) that are not purchased ahead of the official release date.
An unsuitable investment is when an investment— such as a stock or bond—does not meet the objectives and means of an investor.
Unsystematic risk is the risk that is unique to a specific company or industry.
An unusual item is a nonrecurring or one-time gain or loss that is not considered part of normal business operations.
An unweighted index is comprised of securities with equal weight within the index.
To unwind is to close out a trading position, with the term tending to be used when the trade is complex or large.
Up-and-in options are a type of exotic option that is often made available through specialized brokers to high-end clients in the over-the-counter (OTC) markets.
An up-and-out option is a type of knock-out barrier option that ceases to exist when the price of the underlying security rises above a specific price level, called the barrier price.
The up/down gap side-by-side white lines is a three-candle continuation pattern that occurs on candlestick charts.
Up-front mortgage insurance is an insurance premium that is collected, typically on Federal Housing Administration (FHA) loans, at the time the loan is initially made.
The up-market capture ratio is the statistical measure of an investment manager's overall performance in up-markets.
"Up volume" generally refers to an increase in the volume of shares traded in either a market or security that leads to an increase in value.
Upfront pricing refers to the interest rates and limits established for a borrower in a credit card’s underwriting and issuance.
An upgrade refers to the positive change in an analyst's outlook of a particular security's valuation based primarily on that security's improving fundamentals.
The term Uphold refers to a cloud-based financial service platform.
The term upper class refers to a group of individuals who occupy the highest place and status in society.
Upper management includes individuals and teams that are responsible for making the primary decisions within a company.
UPREIT means umbrella partnership real estate investment trust.
Upside refers to the potential increase in value, measured in monetary or percentage terms, of an investment.
The Gap Three Methods is a three-bar Japanese candlestick pattern that indicates a continuation of the current trend.
The upside gap two crows pattern is a three-day candlestick chart formation that signals an upward price move may be running out of momentum and could reverse lower.
An Upside Tasuki Gap is a three-bar candlestick formation that is commonly used to signal the continuation of the current trend.
The term upstairs market refers to a network that exists between large firms and institutional investors.
An upstart is a person who has risen in social rank and/or economic status, but who has yet to be widely accepted by other individuals in the newly found social and economic class.
Upstream is a term for the operations stages in the oil and gas industry that involve exploration and production.

The Upstream Capital Costs Index (UCCI) is a proprietary metric index that tracks the composite capital cost of materials, facilities, equipment, and personnel for oil and natural gas producing projects.
An upstream guarantee, also known as a subsidiary guarantee, is a financial guarantee in which the subsidiary guarantees its parent company's debt.
Uptick describes an increase in the price of a financial instrument since the preceding transaction.

The Uptick Rule (also known as the "plus tick rule") is a rule established by the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) that requires short sales to be conducted at a higher price than the previous trade.
The term uptick volume refers to the volume of shares traded while a stock price rises.
An uptrend describes the price movement of a financial asset when the overall direction is upward.
The Urban Development Act of 1970 is legislation enforced through the U.
